comment._content: Seen on static ‘open house’ display with timber access steps for visitors to view cockpit, a F8U-1E/F-8B Crusader supersonic fighter jet possibly at its home base of MCAS Beaufort South Carolina. Vought F8U-1E/F-8B Crusader 145477 of US Marine Corps VMF-122 ‘Crusaders’ with squadron tail code DC and side number 3 and carrying a blue painted AIM-9 Sidewinder dummy training round on its lower fuselage side pylon. Using F-8Bs, VMF-122 was the first Marine Crusader unit to carrier qualify in 1962, aboard CVA-62 USS Independence, The F-8E replaced the F-8B, and was redesignated a VMF(AW)-122 on October 1, 1962. During the Cuban Missile crisis, the Crusaders deployed to Key West, Florida and remained until December. A temporary shortage of F-8E forced use of F-8B until enough replacements arrived. In 1965 some F-8Bs were used again during transition to F-4B Phantom. gator.crouze.com/chapter6.html (Courtesy of Marko Dirkxx) F-8B 145477 was forward based with VMF(AW)-235 ‘Death Angels’ as side number 5 code DB at MCAS Iwakuni from May1968 to September 1968 when part of Marine Aircraft Group Fifteen (MAG-15) pending the arrival of the F-4 Phantom: www.gonavy.jp/usmc/51/usmc5103c.html (‘GO!NAVY’ info courtesy of Takafumi Hiroe, citizen of Japan & naval aviation historian) Originally designated F8U-1E Crusader, from September 1962 became the F-8B. www.joebaugher.com/navy_fighters/f8_4.html F-8B 145477 was one of 61 rebuilt as F-8L. Most went to Marine Corps squadrons, and a few Navy utility units. F-8L differed from F-8B with underwing pylons and new cockpit lighting system. www.joebaugher.com/navy_fighters/f8_14.html F8U-1E /F-8B/F-8L info courtesy Professor Joe Baugher, Chicago Illinois On 9th March 1970 Vought F-8L Crusader 145477 was involved in a tragic mid-air collision 23 miles from NAS Patuxent River Maryland. US Marine Corps pilot Major Everard E. Hatch was killed when his aircraft collided with another F-8L from the same squadron. The other Crusader lost was F-8L 145497 piloted by USMC Major C. S. McLeran who was able to eject:. www.ejection-history.org.uk/Aircraft_by_Type/F_8_Crusader... This was while with VMF-321 ‘Hells Angels’ Marine Air Reserves fighter squadron based at Naval Air Facility Washington DC, Andrews Air Force Base, Maryland.
